text: Gravity at The Derby Winter Beer Festival. A copper brown colour with a frothy off white head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, some nuts, slight coffee, a little burnt sugar and subtle dark fruits. Taste of chocolate, caramel, some nuts, slight coffee, a little dark fruits, a hint of vanilla and subtle cookie dough. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A soft, dryish, chocolate brownie kind of bitterness to the finish. I like this, sweet like most milds but chocolatey and nutty with a nice bitter finish. Good.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2017 Handpull cask at the Coach & Horses, Wellingborough. Very dark brown, almost with purplish notes. Opaque. Cream-tan head leaves lots of lacing. Chocolate malt aroma with a slight medicinal note. Taste is sweet, smooth and malty. Ovaltine notes are slowly overcome by an insistent but polite hop bitterness. Bittersweet balance in the long finish, with blackberry, red grape and charcoal notes. Tasty mild.

Cask 1/3 pint, gravity dispense, at the 16th Twickenham Beer & Cider Festival, Dark ruby / cola black colour, small beige head. Moderate roasty aroma, notes of mild coffee and dark chocolate. Pleasant and lively mouthfeel. Roasty flavour, coffee and dark chocolate again. Roasty aftertaste, some hops.
Cask gravity at the 2016 Twickenham Beer Festival, very dark brown with a thin head, burnt cocoa nose, dry-sweet and roasty-burnt with cocoa and faint strawberry notes. Very nice.
Cask at Milton Keynes Beer Festival; opaque dark mahogany brown pour with a bubbly off white head, aroma has chocolate, taste has chocolate, slight bitterness, dark fruits, hint of coffee.

Backlog rating. Cask at GBBF 2015. It pours a dark amber color with a minimal beige head. Aroma is sweet malty with notes of biscuit, raisins, caramel, light cocoa and vanilla. Taste is also sweet biscuity with notes of cocoa, vanilla, biscuit. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, tasty mild
Gravity cask at Nottingham festival day two with fonefan, Charlotte & chriso. Deep clear brown color. Very roasty coffee ground aroma. Taste has espresso, burnt brownies. Very nice.

Cask gravity at GBBF 2015 day 2. Mahogany brown caramel coloured with a halo of light cream head. Flavour is composed of nutty toasted grains, semi sweet, dried fruits, slight grainstore. Flavour is composed of nutty, semi sweet, light liquorice, choc. Dried fruit. Palate is eatery. Light semi sweet sugars.
Gravity at Bardfest 2015. Pours deep brown with a frothy cream head. Nice coffee aroma. The taste is very pleasant too. Lots of coffee. Pretty simple and quite thin, but very easy drinking.

Racked Cask at Rugby Tap Micropub.

Poured a dark mahogany brown, with a tan head that soon cleared. 
Roasted aroma with a hint of smoke, A good mild this, very pleasant .

Keighley Beer Festival 2014. Dark with a reddish-brown glow and a thin head. Despite its low strength it feels full-bodied with plenty of roasted malt in both aroma and taste and a subdued but lingering aftertaste.

Aroma: bread and toasted malts. Appearance: dark brown/black, medium beige creamy head. Taste: light bitter and sweet. Palate: toasted and lightly smoky flavours come up quickly. Overall: sub-standard mild, disappointing aroma. Pint at the Crafty Crow, Nottingham.
Pint at the Nags Head in Reading.  Black with bubbly brown head.  Roasty, chocolate, mocha, tasty.  Pleasant light chocolate aroma.  Overall its nice.

A - smokey with coffee
A - dark and hazy with lasting head
T - medicinal bitter
P - mid and soft
O - decent

Cask Handpump at the Kings Head, Huddersfield 15/08/2009
Some fruit and hop aromas. Beige head. Dark red coloured fruity and a little sour with a slight acidic taste. A hint of bitterness in a crisp and dry finish.

Cask at the Live and Let Live, Cambridge. Tar brown in colour with a loose beige head and a striking cherry red colour when held to the light; aroma of roasted malt with smoke and tar mingling; dry in the mouth with a solid chocolate malt body and a light peppery bitterness; then a touch of caramel to finish. Excellent - if only all milds were as good as this.

Handpulled cask at the Pembury Tavern on 15th July 2009, during beer festival. Deep brown-black with a small cream-coloured head. For such a low strength this mild was bursting with flavour. A sharp scent of roasted malts are in the forefront with strong coffee and chocolate notes abounding. A little sophisticated smoke too. First pint at the festival, and absolutely delicious.

[Gravity cask at Milton Keynes beerfest] Vicious foretaste of plums and coffee mellows into the usual dry, toasty mild, but the sour overtones of the plum keep hanging around.  Interesting, and good depth of flavour, but ultimately it didn’t work very well for me.

Cask, Nottingham Fest 08.  Dark brown with a small head.  Aromas are weetabix and chocolate malts with light roast coffee.  Flavours are malty with chocolate and coffee.  Sweet, light, yet tasty.  A simple decent mild.

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008.Clear medium red brown color with a average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, burnt, coffee. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter (malt burnt bitter) with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (020508)

Cask at the Globe, Nottingham. I found this to be a pleasant but unremarkable mild with all the usual sort of aromas and flavours  roast, coffee, etc. It was a textbook case, but without any flair to make it stand out.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2008 First pint at the highly anticipated Merton Winter Festival. Rich chocolate brown, big soapy tan head that lingers attractively. Deep toast aroma, as if one made a concentrate, a reduction sauce, of toast. Nice chocolate accent. Simple, gently sour roast flavor. Just enough body to keep it from feeling unsubstantial, but still a deeply refreshing beer. (If daily gallons of beer like this were still one of the perks of being a miner, perhaps wed still have more mines.) Cracking good mild, and a fine way to start the festival.

Cask conditioned at Merton Winter Beer Festival 08. Dark brown with white head. Dry nutty flavours, perhaps hazelnut, to the fore in this beer, quite bitter from the malt and packs plenty of flavour for the ABV. Some smoky and coffee background notes. An unusual but very decent mild.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2009 Cask at Spoons, Milton Keynes. Dark brown, small off white head. Musty chocolate aroma. roasted taste, quite strong up front. Finish tails off into residual back of throat bitterness. Doesnt have the sour, grainy taste I like in a mild. But its still pretty good. 29.5.09. Cask, gravity, at Northamptonshire Beer Festival 09. Yeasty ashtray aroma develops maltiness. Leathery malt taste with slight sweetness. Dryness dominates the finish. Rated: 5,4,6,4,12: 3.1

Cask conditioned @ Live and Let Live, Cambridge. Dry roasty malt hint of choc. Slightly ashy and smoky. Dry drinkable and refreshing with enough hints of richer flavours to add interest but not enough to overpower the delicate balance.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2008 A Mes rate: Gravicask at Nottingham Beer Festival.Deep dark brown with a redish hue and a beige head. Chocolate malt, coffee, nice biscuit notes and a lovely lick of hops at the finish giving it great balance. A damn good mild, young, drinkable and 100% true to style. Excellent.
Cask gravity at Nottingham BF 2007.  Very dark brown with thin beige head.  Decent bitter choc, roasted malts.  Nice creamy chocolate, really good mild, choccy grainyness is superb, lots of flavour.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 Cask conditioned at the Alexandra Arms, Kettering, Northants, 25-05-07. Poured black with very little head. This was stunning, the aroma was nice and roasty with maybe a touch of woodiness and these key characteristics carried on through into the taste which finished with a nice smoothness, it was simplicity itself but wonderful for it. This beer should really be put up as a benchmark for how a good English Mild should be. There are some great Milds around with Potbelly Beijing Black being one of most memorable of recent years, but it is rare that Ive stumbled across a new mild at the more usual low abv that has had such an impact on me, simply superb.    Updated again at Merton Winter Beer Fesatival Feb 08   This little mild still tastes great, and as Milds go it sets quite a high benchmark, but it isnt quite the force that it was last time out so Im going to have to knock it don a point or two.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2013 Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel Northampton.  An almost black coloured mild with a bitty whitish head.  The aroma is fairly dry with hints of chocolate.  The taste is just  as a dark mild should be - mild!!  Hints of chocolate again and smooth and mellow.Score 3.6Subsequent ratings scored 3.7, 3.8, 3.8, 3.8, 3.9 and 3.6 Average becomes 3.7
